protocol_name: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
protocol_name_html: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
description: The diversity of ribonucleic acid (RNA) viruses in the ocean and the ongoing isolation and characterization of RNA viruses that infect important primary producers suggests that RNA viruses are active members of the marine microbial assemblage. At this point, little is known about the composition, dynamics, and ecology of the RNA virioplankton. In this protocol, we describe a method to assess RNA virus diversity from seawater.

groups.group_name: Suttle Laboratory of Marine Molecular Microbiology and Virology

collections.protocol_name: Characterization of the diversity of marine RNA viruses
collections.protocol_name_html: Characterization of the diversity of marine RNA viruses

authors: Alexander I. Culley, Curtis A. Suttle, and Grieg F. Steward
guidelines:
This protocol is designed to detect picorna-like viruses from marine samples. It is based on a strategy first reported by Culley et al. (2003) and refined by Culley and Steward (2007). All picorna-like viruses have single-stranded positive-sense RNA genomes and are classified in the order Picornavirales (Le Gall et al. 2008). Picorna-like viruses are responsible for several significant human and animal diseases and infect a diversity of marine protists including a diatom (Nagasaki 2008; Lang et al. 2009). The procedure outlined below uses direct filtration of relatively small volumes of water and reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) amplification of an RNAdependent RNA polymerase (RdRP) gene fragment using degenerate primer sets.

With this method, viral polymerase sequences were amplified in several distinct aquatic environments, including an estuarine urban canal (Ala Wai canal, Waikiki, HI, USA), a tropical bay (Kaneohe Bay, HI, USA), and a temperate bay (Monterey Bay, CA, USA). Amplification occurred in samples from the same site in different seasons and at different depths showing that RNA viruses are widespread and consistently present. Sequencing of the amplified gene fragments revealed novel sequences that are highly divergent from any known isolates.

Equipment—Peristaltic pump and pump heads, thermocycler, heating block, incubator, gel electrophoresis unit, electroporator, gel documentation system

Supplies—Sterile, 1.7 mL nucleic acid-free microcentrifuge tubes; 0.2 mL sterile, nucleic acid-free PCR tubes; 0.02 µm aluminum oxide filters (Anotop, Whatman); 10 mL sterile syringes; peristaltic pump tubing; sterile razor blades; MinElute Gel Extraction kit (Qiagen); MinElute PCR Purification kit (Qiagen); Masterpure Complete DNA and RNA Purification kit (Epicenter Biotechnologies); PCRTerminator End Repair kit (Lucigen); CloneSmart HCKan Blunt Cloning kit with Ecloni Supreme cells (Lucigen); Turbo DNA-free Kit (Applied Biosystems)

Solutions, reagents, and media—0.02-filtered, sterile, nucleic acid-free TE buffer (10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA; pH 8); 0.1 M dithiothreitol (DTT); Superscript III Reverse Transcriptase and buffers (Invitrogen); RNase Out (Invitrogen); RNase H (Invitrogen); Platinum Taq DNA polymerase and buffers (Invitrogen)

Primers in concentrations discussed as follows: 0.5 × TBE (45 mM Tris-borate, 1 mM EDTA; pH 8.0) electrophoresis buffer; nucleic acid–free, sterile water; 10 mM dNTP mix.

Table 1: RT and PCR primer details

Name Sequence (5'-3') °C annealing ~Product (bp)
Mpl.sc1F TIGCIGGWGAYTWYARM 50 500
Mpl.sc1R YTCCTTWTCRGSCATKGTA    
Mpl.sc2F ITWGCIGGIGATTWCA 43 500
Mpl.sc2R CKYTTCARRAAWTCAGCATC    
Mpl.sc3F TIATIGMKGGIGAYTA 49 500
Mpl.sc3R TTMARGAAIKMAGCATCTT    
Mpl.cdhF GMIGGTGAYTAYAGCGCTTWYGAY 44 500
Mpl.cdhR ATACCCAATGCCTYTTIARRAA    
RdRp1 GGRGAYTACASCIRWTTTGAT 50 450
RdRp2 MACCCAACKMCKCTTSARRAA    
SL1 CAGTCCAGTTACGCTGGAGTC 50 NA
SR2 GGTCAGGTATGATTTAAATGGTCAGT    
FR26RV-N GCCGGAGCTCTGCAGATATCNNNNNN NA NA
FR40RV-T GCCGGAGCTCTGCAGATATC(T)20 NA NA
FR20RV GCCGGAGCTCTGCAGATATC 65 NA
NA, not applicable

components.data: Whole seawater (if intracellular viruses are to be included in the analysis) or 0.22-filtered seawater (if only the free virus community is targeted) is gently filtered (7 mmHg) through a 0.02 µm aluminum oxide filter (Anotop, Whatman).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Whole seawater (if intracellular viruses are to be included in the analysis) or 0.22-filtered seawater (if only the free virus community is targeted) is gently filtered (7 mmHg) through a 0.02 µm aluminum oxide filter (Anotop, Whatman).

components.data: Filtration should continue until the rate slows dramatically or drops to zero.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Filtration should continue until the rate slows dramatically or drops to zero.

components.data: Use pumped air to remove as much residual sample as possible.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Use pumped air to remove as much residual sample as possible.

components.data: Once dry, seal the filter inlets and outlets with parafilm.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Once dry, seal the filter inlets and outlets with parafilm.
Label the filter.

components.data: Flash-freeze the filter in liquid nitrogen.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Flash-freeze the filter in liquid nitrogen.
Store it at –80°C until extraction.

components.data: Total nucleic acids are extracted from the aluminum oxide filters using a Masterpure complete DNA and RNA Purification kit (Epicenter, Biotechnologies).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Total nucleic acids are extracted from the aluminum oxide filters using a Masterpure complete DNA and RNA Purification kit (Epicenter, Biotechnologies).

source_data.annotation: Although the manufacturers suggest that treated RNA template should not exceed 40% of the total cDNA synthesis reaction, using the reaction discussed below, we have used 55% template without inhibition.
source_data.thread_text: Although the manufacturers suggest that treated RNA template should not exceed 40% of the total cDNA synthesis reaction, using the reaction discussed below, we have used 55% template without inhibition.

components.data: Each cDNA reaction contains 11 µL of extracted Turbo DNA-free–treated RNA template, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, and 100 ng of N6 primer in a total volume of 13 µL.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Each cDNA reaction contains 11 µL of extracted Turbo DNA-free–treated RNA template, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, and 100 ng of N6 primer in a total volume of 13 µL.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 10 of A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.protocol_name: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.protocol_name_html: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.annotation: We have synthesized complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase (Superscript III, Invitrogen) in reactions primed with random hexamers (N6) or the specific primers RdRp2, Mpl.sc1R, Mpl.sc2R, Mpl.sc3R, or Mpl.cdhR (details for these primers are listed in Table 1), and have found no detectable difference in sensitivity between the two approaches. Priming with random hexamers is preferable because the resultant cDNA can be used in a PCR reaction with any of the five primer sets listed in Table 1, eliminating the necessity for a different cDNA reaction for each primer set.
source_data.thread_text: We have synthesized complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase (Superscript III, Invitrogen) in reactions primed with random hexamers (N6) or the specific primers RdRp2, Mpl.sc1R, Mpl.sc2R, Mpl.sc3R, or Mpl.cdhR (details for these primers are listed in Table 1), and have found no detectable difference in sensitivity between the two approaches. Priming with random hexamers is preferable because the resultant cDNA can be used in a PCR reaction with any of the five primer sets listed in Table 1, eliminating the necessity for a different cDNA reaction for each primer set.
source_data.body: We have synthesized complementary DNA (cDNA) using reverse transcriptase (Superscript III, Invitrogen) in reactions primed with random hexamers (N6) or the specific primers RdRp2, Mpl.sc1R, Mpl.sc2R, Mpl.sc3R, or Mpl.cdhR (details for these primers are listed in Table 1), and have found no detectable difference in sensitivity between the two approaches. Priming with random hexamers is preferable because the resultant cDNA can be used in a PCR reaction with any of the five primer sets listed in Table 1, eliminating the necessity for a different cDNA reaction for each primer set.

components.data: Denaturation and annealing of the primers to the RNA template occurs by heating the sample to 65°C for 5 min and then cooling it on ice.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Denaturation and annealing of the primers to the RNA template occurs by heating the sample to 65°C for 5 min and then cooling it on ice.

components.data: While still on ice, DTT (0.5 mM final conc.) is added to the reaction as an enzyme stabilization reagent with 40 U RNase OUT (Invitrogen) to protect the sample from RNAse activity.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: While still on ice, DTT (0.5 mM final conc.) is added to the reaction as an enzyme stabilization reagent with 40 U RNase OUT (Invitrogen) to protect the sample from RNAse activity.

components.data: The complementary DNA strand is synthesized with 200 U Superscript III (Invitrogen) Reverse Transcriptase.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The complementary DNA strand is synthesized with 200 U Superscript III (Invitrogen) Reverse Transcriptase.

components.data: The final reaction volume should be 20 µL.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The final reaction volume should be 20 µL.

components.data: The reaction is incubated initially at 25°C for 5 min so that the relatively unstable hexamer primers remain annealed to the template while cDNA synthesis commences.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The reaction is incubated initially at 25°C for 5 min so that the relatively unstable hexamer primers remain annealed to the template while cDNA synthesis commences.

components.data: The temperature is then increased to 50°C, the temperature at which Superscript III’s processivity is highest, for 60 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The temperature is then increased to 50°C, the temperature at which Superscript III’s processivity is highest, for 60 min.

components.data: The activity of the enzyme is terminated by incubating the reaction at 85°C for 5 min.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The activity of the enzyme is terminated by incubating the reaction at 85°C for 5 min.

components.data: After cDNA synthesis, add 1 µL (2 U) of RNase H (Invitrogen) to the reaction and incubate at 37°C for 20 min to digest the RNA template from the cDNA:RNA molecule.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After cDNA synthesis, add 1 µL (2 U) of RNase H (Invitrogen) to the reaction and incubate at 37°C for 20 min to digest the RNA template from the cDNA:RNA molecule.

components.data: PCR can be performed with the RdRp, Mpl.sc1, Mpl.sc2, Mplsc3, and Mpl.cdh primer sets listed in Table 1 and the cDNA synthesized in the previous step.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: PCR can be performed with the RdRp, Mpl.sc1, Mpl.sc2, Mplsc3, and Mpl.cdh primer sets listed in Table 1 and the cDNA synthesized in the previous step.

components.data: In a 0.2 mL nuclease-free PCR tube, add reaction components to achieve final concentrations of 1× Platinum Taq buffer, 3 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, 1 µM of each primer, and 1 unit of Platinum Taq DNA polymerase (Invitrogen).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In a 0.2 mL nuclease-free PCR tube, add reaction components to achieve final concentrations of 1× Platinum Taq buffer, 3 mM MgCl2, 0.2 mM of each dNTP, 1 µM of each primer, and 1 unit of Platinum Taq DNA polymerase (Invitrogen).

components.data: Incubate the reactions with the following thermal cycling conditions: 94°C for 75 s (this is necessary to activate the enzyme and ensures complete initial denaturation of template), followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94°C for 45 s, annealing at a primer-specific temperature (Table 1) for 45 s, and extension at 72°C for 45 s.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate the reactions with the following thermal cycling conditions: 94°C for 75 s (this is necessary to activate the enzyme and ensures complete initial denaturation of template), followed by 35 cycles of denaturation at 94°C for 45 s, annealing at a primer-specific temperature (Table 1) for 45 s, and extension at 72°C for 45 s.

components.data: Complete the cycle with a single final extension step of 9 min 15 s at 72°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Complete the cycle with a single final extension step of 9 min 15 s at 72°C.

components.data: Before gel separation, we purify and concentrate the PCR reactions with a MinElute PCR cleanup column (Qiagen) as described by the manufacturer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Before gel separation, we purify and concentrate the PCR reactions with a MinElute PCR cleanup column (Qiagen) as described by the manufacturer.

source_data.annotation: A smaller volume of product allows one to load the product on a thinner gel, ultimately resulting in a more efficient recovery of target DNA from the excised band.
source_data.thread_text: A smaller volume of product allows one to load the product on a thinner gel, ultimately resulting in a more efficient recovery of target DNA from the excised band.
source_data.body: A smaller volume of product allows one to load the product on a thinner gel, ultimately resulting in a more efficient recovery of target DNA from the excised band.

components.data: Purified PCR products are loaded onto a 1% agarose gel containing 1× SYBR safe stain (Invitrogen) and 0.5× TBE buffer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Purified PCR products are loaded onto a 1% agarose gel containing 1× SYBR safe stain (Invitrogen) and 0.5× TBE buffer.

components.data: Bands of DNA of the appropriate size (approximately 500 bp) are excised and purified with a MinElute Gel Extraction kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Bands of DNA of the appropriate size (approximately 500 bp) are excised and purified with a MinElute Gel Extraction kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions.

components.data: We recommend eluting DNA from the column with three washes of 10 µL nuclease-free water in preparation for the end repair reaction.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: We recommend eluting DNA from the column with three washes of 10 µL nuclease-free water in preparation for the end repair reaction.

components.data: In preparation for ligation, PCR products are polished and phosphorylated with the PCRTerminator End Repair kit (Lucigen) as described by the manufacturer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: In preparation for ligation, PCR products are polished and phosphorylated with the PCRTerminator End Repair kit (Lucigen) as described by the manufacturer.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 27 of A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.protocol_name: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.protocol_name_html: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.annotation: Several commercial kits are available for the efficient cloning of PCR products. We use the CloneSmart Blunt Cloning kit from Lucigen. Some advantages of this cloning kit are the high efficiency of recombinants that eliminate the need for screening (e.g., XGAL/IPTG) and the prevention of transcription of inserts in the vector reduces cloning bias. However, the pSMART vector requires blunt ends with 5′ phosphate groups (unlike TOPO-TA [Invitrogen] cloning kits for example). The additional step adds time, increases cost, and increases risk of sample loss, but we have found that it works well.
source_data.thread_text: Several commercial kits are available for the efficient cloning of PCR products. We use the CloneSmart Blunt Cloning kit from Lucigen. Some advantages of this cloning kit are the high efficiency of recombinants that eliminate the need for screening (e.g., XGAL/IPTG) and the prevention of transcription of inserts in the vector reduces cloning bias. However, the pSMART vector requires blunt ends with 5′ phosphate groups (unlike TOPO-TA [Invitrogen] cloning kits for example). The additional step adds time, increases cost, and increases risk of sample loss, but we have found that it works well.
source_data.body: Several commercial kits are available for the efficient cloning of PCR products. We use the CloneSmart Blunt Cloning kit from Lucigen. Some advantages of this cloning kit are the high efficiency of recombinants that eliminate the need for screening (e.g., XGAL/IPTG) and the prevention of transcription of inserts in the vector reduces cloning bias. However, the pSMART vector requires blunt ends with 5′ phosphate groups (unlike TOPO-TA [Invitrogen] cloning kits for example). The additional step adds time, increases cost, and increases risk of sample loss, but we have found that it works well.

components.data: After a 15-min incubation at room temperature the reaction is purified and concentrated with a MinElute Reaction Cleanup column (Qiagen).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After a 15-min incubation at room temperature the reaction is purified and concentrated with a MinElute Reaction Cleanup column (Qiagen).

components.data: The eluted PCR products are subsequently ligated into the pSMART-HCKan vector (Lucigen) according to the manufacturer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: The eluted PCR products are subsequently ligated into the pSMART-HCKan vector (Lucigen) according to the manufacturer.

source_data.annotation: In this reaction, we typically use the maximum amount of template (6.5 µL) and the maximum incubation time (2 h).
source_data.thread_text: In this reaction, we typically use the maximum amount of template (6.5 µL) and the maximum incubation time (2 h).
source_data.body: In this reaction, we typically use the maximum amount of template (6.5 µL) and the maximum incubation time (2 h).

components.data: After terminating the ligation reaction by incubating for 15 min at 70°C, 2 µL of the ligation reaction is transformed into Ecloni 10G Supreme cells (Lucigen) via electroporation.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: After terminating the ligation reaction by incubating for 15 min at 70°C, 2 µL of the ligation reaction is transformed into Ecloni 10G Supreme cells (Lucigen) via electroporation.

source_data.protocol_name_html: A degenerate primer reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction protocol to determine the diversity of picorna-like viruses
source_data.annotation: We do not recommend using greater than 2 µL of the ligation mixture in the transformation reaction because the chances of arcing are greatly increased during electroporation.
source_data.thread_text: We do not recommend using greater than 2 µL of the ligation mixture in the transformation reaction because the chances of arcing are greatly increased during electroporation.
source_data.body: We do not recommend using greater than 2 µL of the ligation mixture in the transformation reaction because the chances of arcing are greatly increased during electroporation.

components.data: Before initiating a large-scale sequencing effort, we recommend screening 10 to 20 colonies for inserts by PCR amplification with the primers SL1 and SR2 (Table 1) to assess the quality of the library.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Before initiating a large-scale sequencing effort, we recommend screening 10 to 20 colonies for inserts by PCR amplification with the primers SL1 and SR2 (Table 1) to assess the quality of the library.

components.data: Colony PCR products can be visualized on a gel and the products in the correct size range purified and sequenced.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Colony PCR products can be visualized on a gel and the products in the correct size range purified and sequenced.
